awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Observing the Cosmic Evolution of Neutral Hydrogen
awd_abstract_narration:
Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, and neutral hydrogen atoms are thus an important constituent of interstellar gas in galaxies ? but also one of the most challenging to study. The faintness of neutral hydrogen emission means that it can only be detected beyond the nearby universe via long observations with large telescopes. A new telescope with improved sensitivity, the MeerKAT array, will examine how galaxies' neutral gas reservoirs have evolved over two thirds of the universe's history (i.e., the last nine billion years of cosmic time). It will determine how galaxies' neutral atomic hydrogen content relates to the properties of their stars, their environments, and their cosmic epochs. This will be compared with theoretical predictions in order to understand how gas flows into and out of galaxies and forms new stars while inside galaxies. The research will support the training of graduate and undergraduate students at the four universities; graduate students will gain additional experience in computation and statistics, research mentorship, education in STEM disciplines, and outreach to a variety of audiences.

This survey will probe neutral hydrogen (HI) in emission to an unprecedentedly high redshift of z = 1.45. The combination of individual and stacked HI detections ?  complemented by theoretical modelling, multiwavelength observations, and a rich z = 0 reference dataset ? will probe the evolution of (i) the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation, (ii) the HI mass function, and (iii) the dependence of galaxies' HI content on stellar and dark matter properties. OH megamasers detected as strong line emitters in the MeerKAT data will be used to place constraints on the cosmic history of gas-rich galaxy mergers. Both the HI survey data and the instructional modules used to provide student training will be publicly released as part of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Universe was once a starless place filled with dark cosmic gas. Over time this gas has condensed into stars, such that many bright galaxies like our own have more mass in stars than in interstellar gas. Conversion of gas into stars is expected to depend on where a galaxy sits within the larger cosmic environment (groups or clusters of galaxies and still larger "filaments" made up of such groups) and to evolve over cosmic time. The light of newborn stars has been studied extensively as a function of environment and cosmic time (using the fact that we see distant objects as they were back when their light left them), but quantifying how the gas that forms those stars depends on space and time is harder. The international MeerKAT radio telescope array located in South Africa has recently opened up a new discovery space by making it possible to detect gas reservoirs -- specifically neutral atomic hydrogen or "HI," the most common form of gas -- in ordinary galaxies seen very far away, when the Universe was less than half its present age. Our team is collaborating on one of MeerKAT's Key Programs, the LADUMA (Looking At the Distant Universe with the MeerKAT Array) survey currently underway. In preparation, we worked to build the data and tools necessary to compare the gas inventory of the distant Universe to the local, present-day Universe, with a focus on how the gas available in different environments has evolved.

Intellectual Merit

Measuring evolution requires apples-to-apples comparison. In the local Universe, we can identify galaxy groups consistently with a homogeneous, complete census of galaxies, but in the distant Universe, we must contend with inhomogeneous and incomplete data. Our team updated the local, complete RESOLVE and ECO surveys (http://resolve.astro.unc.edu) and used these surveys in tandem with simulated "mock" surveys to develop a new algorithm for group finding that can reproduce the results found with homogeneous, complete data, yet does not require such perfect information. In fact, the new algorithm is superior to the standard "friends-of-friends" group-finding algorithm in that it more accurately identifies all members of a group without including interlopers.

We used our new algorithm to construct the best measurements to date of the HI inventory as a function of environment, providing a benchmark for measurements soon to be copied by LADUMA. To support this work, we vastly expanded the HI gas inventory of our surveys, both by reprocessing public data to enhance its information content and by developing an algorithm that estimates gas content optimally with partial or missing information. Our analysis of the HI content of groups as a function of group mass clarified tensions between previous estimates and demonstrated that the algorithm used to find groups can strongly affect the result. We also collaborated on an analysis of the HI content of galaxies as a function of their proximity to large-scale filaments of galaxies. This analysis showed that filaments have a secondary but non-negligible effect on the HI content of galaxies, after controlling for the effect of immediate group environment.

These results are reported in Hutchens et al. (2023, Astrophysical Journal, 956, 61) and Hoosain et al. (2023, Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, submitted). We also contributed to two LADUMA-related publications, Glowacki et al. (2022, Astrophysical Journal Letters, 931, L7) and Duncan et al. (2023, The Messenger, 190, 25).

Looking ahead, we reported results at the American Astronomical Society Meeting in June 2022 from our effort to combine HI data with X-ray data (Hutchens et al., in preparation). While cold HI emitting at radio wavelengths is the most important component of galaxy gas reservoirs, hot ionized gas emitting at X-ray wavelengths becomes increasingly prevalent as groups form. The hot gas is too hot to cool and form stars, so we expect the evolving, environment-dependent ratio of cold-to-hot gas to offer insight into patterns of star formation.

Broader Impacts

The RESOLVE/ECO website provides a searchable online database to provide easy access to the data published by our team for both astronomers and the public (http://resolve.astro.unc.edu/pages/database.php). To encourage high school teachers and students to explore the data, we launched the Data Science Portal (DSP -- see http://resolve.astro.unc.edu/pages/outreach.php) with two entry-level tutorials on galaxies, and a third tutorial on dark matter will be classroom tested then posted in the 2024. The DSP also links to more advanced tutorials for college students in the Computational Astronomy & Physics Boot Camp. This research program has contributed to the training of two PhD students and four undergraduates. An additional undergraduate was involved in outreach work for the DSP. The PI and students have also interacted with the public via star parties and public talks.
